metadata.title: Data Lakes, and SQL???. Not a paradox. SQL is being used for… | by Shirish Joshi | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: With greater data volumes, the push is toward newer technologies and paradigm changes. SQL meanwhile has remained the mainstay. Here, I explore how SQL is used with Data Lakes and the new data…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: MapReduce: A Major Step Backward — DeWitt and Stonebraker
The NoSQL discussion has nothing to do with SQL

all_paragraphs: With greater data volumes, the push is toward newer technologies and paradigm changes. SQL meanwhile has remained the mainstay. Here, I explore how SQL is used with Data Lakes and the new data ecosystems.
TL;DR version: SQL is more relevant than ever, with growing data and complexity, for analyzing and transforming data in Data Lakes.
NoSQL databases came onto the scene promising great scalability and simplicity.

If we had to process large amounts of data with variety and volume at high velocity, we were told that NoSQL is the only way out. Vendors kept harping about the impedance mismatch between SQL and middleware code.
We now find most of the NoSQL vendors introducing an SQL layer, after spending years disparaging joins. Some vendors introduced dialects of SQL, making matters worse.
It seemed like the introduction of this SQL layer on NoSQL was driven by fear of new generation databases like Google Spanner, and database vendors offering JSON, XML as first-class datatypes.
Hadoop provided developers with the map-reduce interface, leading to some great advances, but a lot of consternation as well. (See — MapReduce: A Major Step Backward — DeWitt and Stonebraker).
Data processing on Hadoop, using map-reduce, left a lot to be desired. Performance tuning, dealing with data skew, getting the best throughput, all required too many bare-metal code changes.
Multiple SQL inspired approaches were tried out

After many “big data years”, and a few Hadoop mergers and bankruptcies, we now see the survivors of these technologies. Hadoop technologies now live more in the cloud than on-premise. It is less common to see the full Cloudera or HortonWorks stacks in organizations now. Instead, a select few technologies thrived, and now are popularly used in the cloud data stacks.

Stonebraker pointed out a long time ago that the performance issues and scalability of databases have less to do with SQL, and more to do with the design of the database itself (The NoSQL discussion has nothing to do with SQL).
The big advantage of SQL is that it provided familiarity, and the expressiveness to analyze data. The robustness of SQL comes from the foundations of Relational Algebra and Set Theory.
With the Data Lake, here are the technologies we see.
The economics of storage on raw filesystems encourage the creation of data lakes. SQL is used for analysis of that data.
Amazon RedShift Spectrum can query S3 data.
Snowflake DB can use the VARIANT column to store XML, JSON, or ORC data, within the database itself, and also make use of External Tables to point to data in S3.
External tables are also supported with Google BigQuery and Azure SQL Data Warehouse.
ELT (Extract-Load-Transform) paradigm of data processing puts the data transformation step at the very end. The extraction from the source systems, and loading into a database is done first.
The old ETL way of RBAR (Row-By-Agonizing-Row) was in direct contrast with the set-based processing performed by Relational Databases, and set-based processing that formed the basis of SQL.
In ELT, we now extract data from source databases and put it into the data lakes.
SQL transformations are done in the Cloud Data Warehouses or using Presto, and the transformed data is loaded to target tables.

Trickle feeds via GoldenGate, AWS DMS, or using tools like Workato/Jitterbit/StitchData, or a robust event pipeline like Kafka, all feed into Data Lakes or the data warehouses. Minimal transformation takes place between source systems and the loading area. This data then gets transformed and loaded into the warehouses and analytics layer using SQL.
This ELT toolchain uses DAG (Directed Acyclic Graph) tools like Apache AirFlow, and serverless functions, instead of the AutoSys-like schedulers of the old ETL toolchain.

DBT is another tool that is catching on in the transformation space. Cloud data processing tools like FiveTran and Matillion also use SQL and ELT. Domo sequences SQLs to create the transformation pipeline. Looker generates SQL based on LookML.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
